content: I heard a ballot was passed around asking what shows the soldiers wanted on AFN and that Rush was not on the ballot. Apparently enough people wrote him into the ballot to get him on the show? Is this true? I have no idea when this might have happened. Probably around 2002-2004...but not sure.

content: Limbaugh's been on AFN Radio since 1994. In 2004, the search to find a program that would politically balance AFN's talk radio programming began.

content: to explain further. I thought I remembered hearing this on the limbaugh show a few years back and I have claimed it as truth during arguements with some liberals on other forums. Now, I'm being told it is not true. If it isnt, I'll have to admit I'm wrong, and ultimately, that the info you get off of the Rush Limbaugh show is also wrong. I've rejoined the Rush Limbaugh site and then emailed them with this question. anybody?

content: I don't know if it was necessarily "the Dems" who wished it. I do know that a good number of people didn't like the one-sidedness of his shows. On the other side, there was also a good number of people who wanted the entire three hours of his show broadcast on AFN. I myself was not a regular consumer of AFN during my extended period (12 years in Europe), but almost everyone else was. I didn't have a decoder, and only occasionally heard the radio. But I do remember all this. It wasn't a major issue, but it had the appropriate amount of attention.
reply: I don't know if it was necessarily "the Dems" who wished it. I do know that a good number of people didn't like the one-sidedness of his shows.
